Here are a few things you could try to prevent the non-host client from creating multiple games repeatedly:
1. Add a flag or state variable to track if a game is already created. Before creating a new game, check this flag and only create if it is false. Set the flag to true after creating a game.
2. On the non-host client, only attempt to create a game if one doesn't already exist in the database. You can check for existence by querying the database before creating.
3. Implement a "create game" button or action that triggers game creation, rather than having it happen automatically. This way the client has more explicit control over when a new game is created.
4. Add a timestamp to each game entity and only allow creating a new game if the last one was created more than X seconds ago. This adds a throttle to game creation.
5. On game creation success, have the client wait for some event from the host (e.g. game start event) before allowing subsequent game creation. This syncs the two clients.
6. On the server, reject duplicate game creation attempts from the same client based on user ID or other metadata.
The key is adding checks and throttles to prevent rapid repeated game creation, and syncing the two clients so they are in agreement on when a new game should be created.
